page.title: 04Brick making in Fletton - 3
page.content: First the bricks are left to dry out and then they build a wall over the front of the chamber, over which is stuck a horrible slush - this seals the bricks so no air gets in. The wall is called a 'wicket'. Inside the chamber the bricks cook for 100 hours at 980 degrees C. The bricks cook themselves as the clay contains 8% oil which is made from the remains of small sea creatures trapped in the clay millions of years ago. We looked through a hole in the roof of the kiln and saw the red hot bricks burning. We were allowed to take back to school as many finished cooled bricks as we could carry. Some of the children's parents in our class work at the brickyards, often the Italian parents. One boy found a photograph of his grandad working at his very own brick kiln.
